fields.description:
I can't think of a better title, but the steps to reproduce should explain this behavior:

# Create a connection to Active Directory via {{JIRA Administration >> User Directories}}, using *Read Only with Local Groups*. 
# Sync all users from AD , set Default Group Memberships to jira-users and jira-internal
# Login using a testADuser
# Notice that testADuser is automatically added to the groups jira-users and jira-internal
# Logout and login again as admin, this time, change the user object filter in the AD Directory to this:
{code}
(&(objectCategory=Person)(!(sAMAccountName=testADuser)))
{code}
# Sync the directory. Notice that testADuser is not synchronized. 
# Change the user object filter back to:
{code}
(&(objectCategory=Person)(sAMAccountName=*))
{code}
# Sync the directory again, notice that testADuser is synced back, but the user is no longer in jira-users and jira-internal. In this sense, the user indeed, loses all group memberships if they are filtered out from an Active Directory sync (could be due to a failure in any of the Active Directory trees)

h3.Suggestion
Instead of using a regular Active Directory Connector with Local Groups, Consider using Internal with LDAP Authentication (Delegated) Directory instead.
fields.summary: User Loses all Local Group Memberships If Any of the LDAP Syncs Is Unable to Find the User, Even If the User Appears After Subsequent Syncs

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: According to [this example|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Example+-+Basic+Authentication]: - Start JIRA; - Make sure that the Remote APIs are enable; - Create a test user ("user") with a test password ("sphere"); - with the "user":"password" string, encode it in Base64. eg. {noformat} $ echo user:sphere | base64 dXNlcjpzcGhlcmUK {noformat} - Copy the hash and insert it on a GET command against any REST URL. eg: {noformat} curl -D- -X GET -H "Authorization: Basic dXNlcjpzcGhlcmUK" -H "Content-Type: application/json" "http://localhost:8080/rest/api/2/user?username=user" {noformat} Current behavior: JIRA will increase the "Total Failed Login Count" and return a 401 page (Unauthorized) instead a 200 page (OK): {code:html} curl -D- -X GET -H "Authorization: Basic dXNlcjpzcGhlcmUK" -H "Content-Type: application/json" "http://localhost:8080/rest/api/2/user?username=user" HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1 X-AREQUESTID: 1119x69x1 X-Seraph-LoginReason: AUTHENTICATED_FAILED WWW-Authenticate: OAuth realm="http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A8080" Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=5CA1FAF6A7D032075EFAD662B2B86D87; Path=/; HttpOnly Content-Type: text/html;charset=UTF-8 Transfer-Encoding: chunked Date: Thu, 09 Aug 2012 21:39:21 GMT Unauthorized (401)

Unauthorized (401)

Encountered a 401 - Unauthorized error while loading this page.

JIRA home

{code} Expected behavior: JIRA must accept the base64 hash as a valid credential. As it turns out, it is working with a text-plain valid credential: {code:html} curl -D- -u user:sphere -X GET -H "Content-Type: application/json" "http://localhost:8080/rest/api/2/user?username=user" HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1 X-AREQUESTID: 1118x68x1 Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=8A84550BA6F69BA46DE599B6653492E7; Path=/; HttpOnly X-Seraph-LoginReason: OK Set-Cookie: atlassian.xsrf.token=BFC6-CB39-H9P6-XYC9|4ee3a8893553cb69c4613a8b132a0c19ea9e9cd9|lin; Path=/ X-ASESSIONID: 1pp1sxd X-AUSERNAME: user Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, no-transform Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8 Transfer-Encoding: chunked Date: Thu, 09 Aug 2012 21:38:13 GMT {"self":"http://localhost:8080/rest/api/2/user?username=user","name":"user","emailAddress":"test@test.com","avatarUrls":{"16x16":"http://localhost:8080/secure/useravatar?size=small&avatarId=10122","48x48":"http://localhost:8080/secure/useravatar?avatarId=10122"},"displayName":"test user","active":true,"timeZone":"America/Sao_Paulo","groups":{"size":1,"items":[]},"expand":"groups"} {code} Best regards, Lucas Timm Atlassian Support
fields.summary: REST API retrieving 401 instead 200 when specifying a valid base64 hash as Basic authentication header

This is about:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Adding+the+Activity+Stream+Gadget
In the Adding the 'Activity Stream' gadget to your Dashboard section

I ran some tests with JIRA5+ and Conf 3.5.x and 4.x versions.

I found that if connecting JIRA 5+ to Conf 3.5.x, you don't get the option to disable the stream from Conf in activity streams. This only appears when connecting JIRA 5+ to Conf 4+.

I logged this for a customer who ran into this issue and thought it'd be a good idea to have the documents note that.

Thanks!

fields.description:

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29281].
  {panel}

On The Activity Stream, if the source code path to the code in FishEye contains a space, Jira automatically fills this space with an "+" instead of a "%20" and as a result, these links are broken and produce a file not found error.

!ActivityStreamChangedSet.png!

However, clicking the same changeset on the SourceTab, the spaces will be defined as %20, and this will lead to the correct link.

!SourceTabChangedSet.png!
fields.summary: FishEye changeset link from the Activity Stream will uses + rather %20 for spaces

A new user should just be added to jira-users.

Best regards,
Frank Blechschmidt
Hasso-Plattner Institute Potsdam, Germany

fields.description:
h3. Summary of Bug

When using the Scheme Comparison Tool, it does not filter the schemes according to whether it is under Permission Scheme or Notification Scheme. Instead, it lists all the schemes. 

For the 'Associated' tab, it shows all schemes that is associated to projects, no matter whether the dropdown filter is set to Permission scheme or Notification scheme. 
!scheme1.png|thumbnail!

For the 'All' tab, it shows all of the permission schemes and notification schemes that is created in the instance. 
!scheme2.png|thumbnail!

Comparing two different type of schemes (permission and notification scheme) returns an error message :
{{Unable to resolve a scheme for the id: 10100}}
!scheme3.png|thumbnail!

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Access the JIRA 'Scheme Comparison Tool' located in the 'Scheme Tools' option in the JIRA administration menu
# Try to filter the schemes according to Permission or Notification schemes

h3. Details
* If you try to compare the 'Default Notification Scheme' with the 'Default Permission Scheme', it seems to be able to do so with no problem. 
* Note that for the first image, 'Mine Notice' is a notification scheme, while 'His' is a permission scheme.
fields.summary: Scheme Comparison tool does not filter schemes

fields.description:
I am running the issue collector on an embedded Confluence page and have linked the users through embedded crowd to my JIRA instance.
When logged in as User X using the issue collector, the issue will list the default *Issue Reporter* rather than the logged in user.

The only workaround, is to manually enter in User X's email address when creating the issue which then lists the correct reporter.

Assumptions
* JIRA user directory linked to Confluence using embedded crowd
* Users X and Y have Admin privileges on project

Steps to Reproduce
# Create Project X in JIRA 
# Create Issue Collector for Project X
#* Select User X as the Default Issue Reporter
#* Select *_Attempt to match user session of submitter or submitter email address_* for *_Match Reporter_* setting
# Embed the html into confluence
# Log into confluence as User Y and create issue through Issue Collector
# Because you are logged in as User Y, and User Y exists in JIRA, we expect the reporter to be User Y, but instead defaults to User X.
fields.summary: Issue Collector Embedded in Confluence does not assign the logged in User as the reporter

fields.description:
The custom fields administration screen takes a long time in JIRA 5.1 and the tests show that the database queries performed while loading the custom fields have become 4 times the values shown in JIRA 4.4.5.

With around 750 custom fields it takes around 3 minutes for the ViewCustomFields screen to load.

The related support case can be accessed here: [JSP-134041|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-134041] and the test report is in this [direct link|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-134041?focusedCommentId=2793628&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-2793628] to the detailed comment.

h5. Comparison Tests with Sample Data
* Two Projects
* Two Multi Select Custom Fields (one with global context, one with four specific issue types and specific to two projects)
* Two Options Each
||Database||JIRA Version||No. of SELECT Queries||
|PostGresSQL|5.1|16 (4 times of 4.4.5)|
|PostGresSQL|4.4.5|4|
fields.summary: JIRA View Custom Fields Page Performance Issues

fields.description:
I've seen a number of support issues now where a schema was set incorrectly (MySQL should never have a schema set) for MySQL which causes these errors in the logs:
{noformat}
2012-07-31 09:45:37,179 main WARN      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Entity "Action" has no table in the database
2012-07-31 09:45:37,242 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Could not create table "jira5.jiraaction"
2012-07-31 09:45:37,242 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] SQL Exception while executing the following:
CREATE TABLE jira5.jiraaction (ID DECIMAL(18,0) NOT NULL, issueid DECIMAL(18,0), AUTHOR VARCHAR(255), actiontype VARCHAR(255), actionlevel VARCHAR(255), rolelevel DECIMAL(18,0), actionbody LONGTEXT, CREATED DATETIME, UPDATEAUTHOR VARCHAR(255), UPDATED DATETIME, actionnum DECIMAL(18,0), CONSTRAINT PK_jiraaction PRIMARY KEY (ID))
Error was: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLSyntaxErrorException: Table 'jiraaction' already exists
2012-07-31 09:45:37,242 main WARN      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Entity "Application" has no table in the database
2012-07-31 09:45:37,243 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Could not create table "jira5.cwd_application"
2012-07-31 09:45:37,243 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] SQL Exception while executing the following:
CREATE TABLE jira5.cwd_application (ID DECIMAL(18,0) NOT NULL, application_name VARCHAR(255), lower_application_name VARCHAR(255), created_date DATETIME, updated_date DATETIME, active DECIMAL(9,0), description VARCHAR(255), application_type VARCHAR(255), credential VARCHAR(255), CONSTRAINT PK_cwd_application PRIMARY KEY (ID))
Error was: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLSyntaxErrorException: Table 'cwd_application' already exists
2012-07-31 09:45:37,243 main WARN      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Entity "Avatar" has no table in the database
2012-07-31 09:45:37,244 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] Could not create table "jira5.avatar"
2012-07-31 09:45:37,244 main ERROR      [core.entity.jdbc.DatabaseUtil] SQL Exception while executing the follo
{noformat}

The problem is that this doesn't stop JIRA from starting.  JIRA will start up but it can't modify the DB tables which can cause issues when upgrading JIRA.  This causes data inconsistencies that are hard to deal with in support.

Should be fairly trivial to write a startup check to guard against this and stop JIRA from starting up!
fields.summary: Add a startup check to stop JIRA from starting if a schema is set with MySQL

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create 2 projects in JIRA, PROJA and PROJB.
# Create a custom field of any type (tested with user picker field), and *set the context to PROJB only*
# Create an issue in PROJA
# *Bulk move* that issue to PROJB (notice that the custom field created earlier is *required*, even though it is clearly *optional*)
# Move that issue individually, *without bulk move*. (notice that the custom field created earlier is *not required* - Expected behavior)

h3.Observation
Even though the field is flagged as required during the bulk move you can submit the form without inputting any values into the field (so technically, it is still optional, but the asterisk is misleading to users)
fields.summary: Optional custom fields marked as required when performing a bulk move operation from one project to another

  {panel}

The current workflow designer is very clumsy and takes huge amount to time to format existing workflow design. Given the problems mentioned by other users, it would be good to allow uploading of images directly.

Advantages:
* There are good and easy designers in the market which generates images, those images are very to upload (Like Avatars).
* Sometimes we edit the workflow and skip some statuses. However, we cannot remove those statuses from WF because WF is active. It never use to be visible before but now you see the obsolete status like an island in the WF diagram.
fields.summary: Workflow designer should allow to upload images.

  {panel}

If you attach a screenshot in jira 5.1.1 you can't see any progress of the upload. You simple need to belive that something is happening in the backgound, if the upload is complete everything is fine and the images appeare under the appropriate section. Some of our users are very irritated that their upload or screenshot attachment didn't work because of the lack of any visual feedback while the file is beeing process in the background. You may implement some kind of loading gif that appears until the image appears. That would get the casual user happy.

Thank you in advance for looking into that.

Regards,
Björn

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29243].
  {panel}

The issue JRA-28788 was raised as Labels could not be inline-edited on the view-issue page if the Labels field was not in the Edit Screen. In previous versions of JIRA it was possible to edit the labels field even if the field was not present in the Edit Screen. 

It has been decided not to restore this behaviour in JIRA 5.1 and beyond so an alternative to inline editing Labels needs to be documented.

There are two options:
# Press the 'l' key to bring up the Labels dialog
# Add the Labels field to the Edit Screen

Further, to increase visibility of the issue, it was proposed that the JIRA Admin Helper Plugin be used to help diagnose why people cannot edit a particular field. Currently the plugin does not load the Edit Screen details on the View Issue page. I will raise an issue with the developer to see if this is possible.
fields.summary: Knowledge base entry for Inline Editing Labels field

Oracle and SQL Server have restrictions for the maximum number of parameters in the IN clause. This method is unbounded, it means that it will fail if some plugin passes more input issues than the DB allows.

fields.description:
During import of XML data i got the error that the column "SUMMARY" of the table "JIRAISSUES" is too small for 259 characters (defined for 255).
This is because there are some Unicode characters in the summary which had exceeded the size of 255 bytes (but not chars)

To solve the problem i had to drop the new database and modify the oracle10 entity definition file where i had to change all VARCHAR2(xx) to VARCHAR2(xx CHAR).
Then the schema got created and i could import all data without a hassle.

More information:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/81448/difference-between-byte-and-char-in-column-datatypes
fields.summary: oracle10 entity definition should use VARCHAR2(xx CHAR) instead of VARCHAR2 (xx)

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29226].
  {panel}


Roger Symonds
27 Jul (10 days ago)

to Josh 
Hi Josh, 

Hope you're doing well!

Quick note, it would be great if JIRA had a default "Home" directory set and configured. In the wizard this could be checked with the user and if a custom home directory was provided, update the config AND add a symbolic link in the default home directory which points to the custom home directory.
* Makes it much easier to spin up a new instance of JIRA (for new admins, evaluators, etc. don't need to configure a home directory - just use the default)
* Provides a standard place for the home directory (easier to support, more predictable - allows creation of help scripts etc.)
* If a custom home directory is provided it's still easy for an Admin to see where it is (from the symbolic link in the standard home directory)
I like the new drop down over the JIRA logo (to allow for switching instances), this will help with federation later, and usability (easy for users to find the other Atlassian products, they feel more connected/associated/related and consistent). 
Sounds a little like this issue raised in December '08: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-13976  :-)

Cheers,
Roger

Roger Symonds

CustomWare | Sydney, Australia | www.customware.net | roger@customware.net
Australia: +61 2 9900 5733 | Mobile: +61 421 556 995 | Skype: roger.symonds | Twitter: rogersymonds

Connect Salesforce.com and Atlassian Confluence with CustomWare - http://ow.ly/crFgn

-----------
Josh Devenny jdevenny@atlassian.com
11:03 (7 hours ago)

to me 
Hey Rog,

Thanks for the suggestion! I do agree with you that this would be rather helpful for those installing JIRA, however our focus at the moment is on project-administration, as well as viewing/editing issues.

Have you raised a ticket on JAC for this? Just so we can track it when we eventually get back to working on the installers.

Cheers
Josh

	at com.atlassian.util.concurrent.LazyReference.getInterruptibly(LazyReference.java:143)
	... 41 more
{code}

The *danger* here is that the above stacktrace fills the logs over and over again, in some cases flooding them so much disk space has become a concern for the customer.

Two ideas to fix this:
* Make the errors less verbose (only really needs to come up once per busted plugin)
* Warn the admin user in the header what is happening (and possibly which plugin is causing it) so that they can fix this themselves not requiring support intervention (this may need to be a feature)
fields.summary: 'java.lang.IllegalStateException: Bundle is uninstalled' Errors in JIRA log files too verbose

Hi team

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29213].
  {panel}

Starting JIRA 5.1, the embedded crowd has been upgraded from version 2.3.2 to 2.4. This includes the security fix [CWD-2690] (won't be visible to public) that has been announced in Crowd 2.3.6 release notes - [Crowd 2.3.6 Release Notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+2.3.6+Release+Notes].

In JIRA, this has caused a lot of issues to customers with SSL-ed LDAP integration. Mainly because JIRA used to not verify that the server's SSL certificate is valid for the host name in the LDAP connection URL.

In Crowd, one can still have the old behaviour by workarounding it:
{quote}
As a workaround for deployments where there is an expected difference, using an 'ldaps' connection URL and leaving 'Secure SSL' unchecked will preserve the previous behaviour and make an SSL connection but will not verify that the hostname and certificate match.
{quote}

However, in JIRA, once you enable "Use SSL", there is no way we can fallback to the old behaviour like Crowd above.
!SSL_UserDirectory.png!

This feature request is to propose to have similar config/option like Crowd to allow an SSL LDAP connection but without verifying that the hostname and certificate match (fix of CWD-2690).

h5. Workaround options

# Fix the certificate to contain the correct name. This is the preferred (and most secure) fix.
# Edit /etc/hosts on the LDAP server to allow you to use the incorrect name in the certificate. Add the FQDN on the certificate and match it to the IP address of the server.
# (!) Backup Confluence database beforehand for safety purpose
#- Run the following SQL query:
{code}
UPDATE cwd_directory_attribute
SET attribute_value='false'
WHERE attribute_name='ldap.secure'
AND directory_id  = <desired_directory_ID>;
{code} 
#- Restart JIRA
#- (i) *Note*: The above option will always reverted to its default ('true') whenever you edit the user directory settings. Therefore, you'll need to run that query every time you do any changes on the user directory settings.
fields.summary: Add an option in User Directory settings to make an SSL LDAP connection but without verifying that the hostname and certificate match

  {panel}

The *Date Time* custom field does not comply to the rules of configuration of "Date/Time Formats" from the Look and Feel. Kindly refer to the attached screenshots.

*Example*: Complete Date/Time Format 	dd/MMM/yy HH:mm

*Workaround prior to 4.4* 
# Shutdown JIRA instance
# Create the *jira-config.properties* in your {{JIRA Home Directory}}
# Insert the following into the file (example: dd/MMM/yy HH:mm) or other format that you want to have
{code}
jira.date.picker.javascript.format = %e/%b/%y
jira.date.time.picker.javascript.format = %e/%b/%y %H:%M
jira.date.time.picker.java.format = dd/MMM/yy HH:mm
jira.date.picker.java.format = dd/MMM/yy
{code}
# Delete the contents of {{JIRA Installation Directory\work}} directory
# Restart JIRA instance

*Workaround 4.4 and later*
# Go to _General Configuration > Advanced_
# Configure the format as below
{code}
jira.date.picker.javascript.format=%e/%b/%y
jira.date.time.picker.javascript.format=%e/%b/%y %H:%M
jira.date.time.picker.java.format=dd/MMM/yy HH:mm
jira.date.picker.java.format=dd/MMM/yy
{code}
fields.summary: Custom Field "Date Time" is not following the format on the "Date/Time Formats"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29202].
  {panel}

When LDAP users are deleted in the LDAP server JIRA will automatically delete the users on JIRA side during the next synchronization.

This behavior would cause a known issue which is documented on knowledge base article here:

* [Issues associated to users deleted from LDAP or crowd can not be reassociated to a different user|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Issues+associated+to+users+deleted+from+LDAP+or+crowd+can+not+be+reassociated+to+a+different+user]

It would be great if JIRA would be able to do the following scenarios:

*Option 1*
# User deleted on LDAP server
# JIRA synchronize with LDAP server and understand that there are missing users
# JIRA check if the users have created any content on JIRA
# If the users have created any content JIRA would keep the users and deactivate it for licensing purposes

*Option 1*
# User deleted on LDAP server
# JIRA synchronize with LDAP server and understand that there are missing users
# JIRA check if the users have created any content on JIRA
# JIRA deleted the user on LDAP directory
# Re-create the user in "Internal Directory"
# Deactivate it for licensing purposes
fields.summary: JIRA Should Handle Deleted LDAP User(s) Better

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29200].
  {panel}

This error message appears often, in JIRA logs:

{panel}
Method getHtml threw exception for reference $column in template templates/jira/issue/table/issuetable-issue.vm
{panel}

This message is a symptom, not a root cause, from what I can tell. Here's what I found:

# I think [this is the best description of it|https://github.com/garyhodgson/tinymce-renderer-plugin/issues/30]:
bq.  If my search result contiains and issue for which myField is null/empty, then I get an error in the Jira search, as well as an exception in my Jira log. If modify my entry to have a non-Null/blank field in myField, then the Entry Navigator works as expected, with no errors returned.
# Looking through [SAC tickets|https://support.atlassian.com/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&jqlQuery=summary+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+OR+description+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+OR+comment+~+%22%5C%22Method+getHtml+threw+exception+for+reference%5C%22%22+ORDER+BY+created+DESC] (*note*: these are not public), we have what would appear to be 45 different root causes, including NPEs, Illegal Argument exceptions, GreenHopper Rank exceptions, even OutOfMemory Errors. They apply to all different custom field types. 

*Improvement Request*
In general I'm thinking this is an innocuous error, given that the true root cause is what error message appears below it (the NPE or otherwise), but perhaps it's worth implementing better error handling to indicate which custom field has the problem, and for which issue ID. This error is spamming the logs and is quite common.

*Workaround*
If you're a customer and are seeing this issue in your environment, look at the stacktrace error below this one to identify a true root cause.
fields.summary: Handle 'Method getHtml threw exception for reference $column in template templates/jira/issue/table/issuetable-issue.vm' errors more gracefully

When JIRA does not have enough permission to read its own {{crowd.properties}} it will return the following stack trace:

{code}Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: org.apache.commons.httpclient.URIException: URI-Reference required
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor.<init>(RestExecutor.java:78)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.<init>(RestCrowdClient.java:78)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.factory.RestCrowdClientFactory.newInstance(RestCrowdClientFactory.java:26)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.factory.RestCrowdHttpAuthenticationFactory.createInstance(RestCrowdHttpAuthenticationFactory.java:43)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.factory.RestCrowdHttpAuthenticationFactory.<clinit>(RestCrowdHttpAuthenticationFactory.java:21)
Caused by: org.apache.commons.httpclient.URIException: URI-Reference required
at org.apache.commons.httpclient.URI.parseUriReference(URI.java:1874)
at org.apache.commons.httpclient.URI.<init>(URI.java:165)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor.<init>(RestExecutor.java:59){code}

The above stack trace does not provide the necessary information to troubleshoot the issue as its only mentioned that the URL inputted in {{crowd.properties}} is incorrect which is not the case.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29194].
  {panel}

Let me explain the situation first.

We have clients speaking different languages, so ideally they should see the login page in their own language, not the system's default locale. But since we also have a much larger user base poorly understanding English, we're keeping our system locale set to Russian, and that confuses our English-speaking clients.
What we need right now is the ability to over-ride default language for only the login page without touching the system locale, with, say a parameter (login.jsp?lang=en). Is that even possible with the current release of JIRA?

Another possible way would be to automatically detect users' locale based on browser settings.
fields.summary: Please add the ability to override language of the login page (or browser-based locale detection)

Upon project import, if a customfield has an invalid context please throw a better exception or perhaps even just ignore the field entirely and show a warning (since it doesn't have a valid context it doesn't show up anywhere and thus can't have any data).

Andreas Knecht has offered the following ideas on this:
{quote}
I think the BackupOverBuilderImpl.getCustomFieldConfigurations() method could have a try catch or something for this problem and then print the appropriate warning.
{quote}

The reason for this is currently if an import is done with a field invalid context an NPE is thrown giving no more information about the problem.

Current error:
{code}
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.core.BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.getIssueTypesList(BackupOverviewBuilderImpl.java:282)

	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.importer.project.ProjectImportSelectBackup$BackupOverviewCallable.call(ProjectImportSelectBackup.java:236)
	at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.importer.project.ProjectImportSelectBackup$BackupOverviewCallable.call(ProjectImportSelectBackup.java:224)
	at com.atlassian.jira.task.TaskManagerImpl$TaskCallableDecorator.call(TaskManagerImpl.java:358)

Crowd Embedded doesn't currently synchronise a user's primary group, as per the attached screenshot. It looks like this is because it's not a {{memberOf}} object, as in the sample LDIF below:

Can you please improve the Embedded Crowd engine in JIRA so that it imports the primary group of the user? Thanks!

h5. Workaround

Set up the User Directory so that it uses the [Default Group Membership|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+to+an+LDAP+Directory#ConnectingtoanLDAPDirectory-AddingUserstoGroupsAutomatically] functionality. This will require a permission setting of Read Only, with Local Groups. This won't bring over the Primary Group, however it will let you set a default group for *all* users.

  {panel}

We need some kind of advise regarding the JIRA Structure plugin, e.g. is this future safe solution? It seems to fill a significant functional gap so why did'nt Atlassian make such a function in the first place? This Igor Sereda (who seems to be an extremely bright guy by the way), does he run a one man show? If so, do we dare to go that way, is that really future safe??? (our products have a very long life cycle!!!)
 
We have several JIRA projects representing both the delivery product level and (often common) sub-products on various levels. For a few projects we use GreenHopper since long and now we tink that Rapid Board seems to be one way to start using Greenhopper for more products as we can span over several JIRA projects that way.

But some people here are interested in the Structure plugin and such a choice seems me - to some extent - be an alternative to use Rapidboard.

So I really need some kind of product road map though I know that that is not in line with the policy of Atlassian.

Or could we get some kind of statement from Atlassian regarding the future of the Structure plugin or the functionality it represents?

Please!!
fields.summary: Is the JIRA Structure Plugin consistenet with JIRA medium or long time product planning.
